supportDesc.support: All medieval leaves are of parchment (HFFH).

foliation.note: Folio designations 82-83, 91 and 105 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).
Foliated in the upper outer corner of each recto in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals.

collation.p: This manuscript is a composite volume comprised of 16 quires from three originally separate sources. Quires 11 and 13 are both irregular. Annotations by H.L. Pink on ff. 92r and 106r show that it was previously thought that each of these quires lacked a leaf. However, comparison of the text in this volume with that found in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 79 confirms that no text is missing, which would ordinarily point to these leaves having been cancelled. The typical arrangement in this volume is 'HFFH', meaning the hair side faces outwards on each quire, and the sides match across openings: hair sides facing hair sides, and flesh sides facing flesh sides. However, irregularities in the disposition of hair and flesh sides in the leaves of parchment in these quires point to more complicated changes having taken place.

In Quire 11, the hair/flesh sequence continues normally until f. 88v (=flesh) and f. 89r (=hair). Folios 89-90 are a bifolium, after which may be seen a stub that is conjoint with f. 88. However, there is no irregularity in the hair/flesh sequence at this juncture: f. 90v (=hair) and f. 92r (=hair). It appears, therefore, that at the time of production the scribe replaced or inverted the 6th and 7th leaves of the quire, arranging them with the flesh side facing inwards (rather than outwards, as would have been the usual arrangement), as well as cancelling the 8th leaf. The intention may perhaps have been to disguise the cancellation by arranging the leaves in such a way that an interruption to the disposition of the leaves was disguised.

In Quire 13, a similar pattern of behaviour is detectable. Although the 2nd leaf has been cancelled (after f. 104), there is no interruption to the disposition there: f. 104v (=flesh) and f. 106r (=flesh). The stub that is visible between these leaves is conjoint with f. 112. At that location, however, there is an interruption to the disposition: f. 112v (=hair) and f. 113 (=flesh). Again, after having made a cancellation, the scribe appears to have rearranged the disposition of the remaining bifolia, disguising the removal of the leaf at this place where the cancellation was made.

Quire 15 is more difficult to construe correctly, it comprises six single leaves, now stitched behind Quire 14 and of an uncertain original structure; the disposition of hair and flesh sides suggests that they may have once been part of a quire, or else have been arranged to reflect the typical arrangement of the leaves in a quire.

The collation of the volume can be described as follows:
Quire 110-5 (ff. 1-5: 6th-10th leaves cancelled) |
Quires 2-38 (ff. 6-21)
Quire 412 (ff. 22-33)
Quire 58 (ff. 34-41)
Quire 610 (ff. 42-51)
Quires 7-98 (ff. 52-75)
Quire 108-2 (ff. 76-81: 7th and 8th leaves, ff. 82-83 excised, probably blank)
Quire 1112-1 (ff. 84-95: one leaf cancelled; see above for further details))
Quire 128 (ff. 96-103)
Quire 1310-1 (ff. 104, 106-113: one leaf cancelled; see above for further details)
Quire 144-1 (ff. 114-116: 1st leaf cancelled) |
Quire 15six (ff. 117-122: six single leaves stitched behind Quire 14)
Quire 168 (ff. 123-130)
collation.formula: 110-5 (6th-10th leaves excised) | 2-38 412 58 610 7-98 108-2(7-8th leaves excised) 1112-1 (one leaf cancelled) 128 1310-1 (one leaf cancelled) 144-1 (1st leaf cancelled) | 15six 168

signatures.p: No leaf signatures pertaining to the entire volume.

Beginning at Quire 2, quires are numbered 1-14 in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire; readers should be aware that all of the quire designations in pencil in the volume are '1' lower than described in this record.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords pertaining to the entire volume.

note.p: The inner face of the right board contains a collation statement in pencil, by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L. .

binding.p: Bound in the (?first half) of the 17th century. Rebacked. Fully bound in leather over millboards with matching decoration on both covers. Each cover is decorated in blind with a triple-fillet frame with Oxford corners set at the perimeter of the boards, and an additional triple-fillet parallel with the joints and inset by c. 10mm. Five raised bands on spine. Spine compartments are decorated with a double-fillet at the upper and lower perimeter of each compartment. Title of the volume 'PLATEARIUS' tooled in gold in one compartment, and the shelfmark, 'Dd.3.51' tooled in gold in another. No pastedowns; inner faces of the boards exposed. Head, fore, and tail edges of the bookblock stained red.

The inner face of the left board contains:
A King George I donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 present on the inner face of the left board
A 'D' in pencil for a size-based classification subsystem in use at CUL
A 'Gray Cambridge' stamp added in 1954 when the volume was repaired by the Gray bindery, and a date in ink recording the date of the work ..-12-1954

history.provenance: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 no. 10 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697) (p. 361).
history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 present on the inner face of the left board.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press), no. 55; and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M. R. James Montague Rhodes James , now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.3.51, ff. 1r-5v

title.supplied: Tabule cum commento Johannis de Sancto Paulo

msItem.author: Richardus Medicus
msItem.rubric: prima tabula salerni . Columpna prima emagoga
msItem.note: Lower part of ff. 2 and 5 cut off.

Similar versions of this text in:
Cambridge, Peterhouse MS 178, ff. 1r-9r
Paris, Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal, MS 1025, ff. 83r-88r
London, British Library, MS Sloane 418, ff. 328-332

listBibl.bibl: Printed in Collectio Salernitana: ossia documenti inediti, e trattati di medicina appartenenti alla scuola medica Salernitana, eds. Renzi et al., 5 vols (Naples, 1852-1859) vol. 5, 234-253.

msItem.title: Medical note
msItem.incipit: 5v saporum autem viiio sunt species v pertinent ad calorem tres ad frigitatem
msItem.explicit: 5v maturitatem accedunt stiptica sunt vel quam Iustrumem ... quotunt constringunt secundum pontica magis
msItem.note: Written in a cursive 16th-century hand

supportDesc.condition: Historic repairs to the parchment. Lower parts of ff. 2 and 5 cut off.

layout.seg: Four columns with 48 lines to the page, frame- and line ruled in brown ink. Written above the top line. Fifteen vertical bounding lines, all extending the hight of the page. The first, the third, the third last and the last horizontal bounding lines extending almost the width of the page.

handNote.p: Written in the libraria form of northern textualis.

decoNote.p: Rubrication in red in on f. 1r; unfilled spaces left for rubrication on ff. 1v-5r.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.3.51, ff. 6r-116v

msItem.title: Commentary on Antidotarium Nicolai ('Liber iste')
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius
msItem.incipit: 6r Liber iste quem in presensentiarum legendum assumptimus ex multorum antidotis est compilatus
msItem.note: Rubric added in a ?16th-century English hand.
Folio 19v blank, presumably owing to the poor quality of the parchment.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 41v Secundum magistrum Paulum de Middelburgo pilule iste sequentes optime purgant
msItem.explicit: 41v sirupo de eupatorio . sitque pillularum dosis dragma .I. aut plus aut minus
msItem.note: Recipe added in a ?15th-century ?English hand.

The recipe refers to a Magister Paulum de Middelburgo ('Master Paul of Middleburgh'), perhaps Paulus de Middelburg Paulus de Middelburg, 1455-1534 , a medieval scientist and the bishop of Fossombrone.

msItem.title: Practica brevis
msItem.author: Joannes Platearius
msItem.rubric: Tractatus Johannis Platearii de passionibus et earum curis
msItem.incipit: 42r Amicum induit qui iustis amicorum precibus condescendit
msItem.explicit: 80r ut desiccetur puluis inde factus cum licinio fistule inmittatur .
msItem.note: Rubric added in the upper margin in a 16th-century English hand.
Prologue on f. 42r: 'Amicum induit qui iustis amicorum precibus condescendit ... optatum prebuit effectum '

listBibl.bibl: Victoria Recio Muñoz (ed. transl. comm.) La "Practica" de Plateario Firenze, SISMEL. Edizioni del Galluzzo 2016 (Edizione nazionale dei testi mediolatini d'Italia 40), pp. 121-801 (manuscript C, p. 81)

msItem.title: Note on urine
msItem.incipit: 80r Nota quod quodam urina in mulieribus apparens salutis est signum
msItem.explicit: 80r non est bonum signum . set mortale . Set maxime in peripleumonico. et pleuretico

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by another hand, possibly English.

msItem.title: De signis bonitatis medicamentorum
msItem.explicit: 81v Dyagridium subtilis subere interius lucidum apositum lingue lactescens, bonum .
msItem.note: The list ends abruptlyly, most of 81v is empty.

msItem.title: De febribus acutis
msItem.note: A break occurs after section on Malum mortuum

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Added in the 13th century.

msItem.title: Decoctiones
msItem.author: ?Maurus
msItem.explicit: 116r mercurialis Lapaci Acuti et Aceti et scabiose de omnibus illis abluantur tibie
msItem.note: The Maurus of the title may be Maurus Salernitanus Maurus Salernitanus

msItem.title: Medical definitions and recipes
msItem.incipit: 116v Epaticis id est apostema . circa epar . Calculosis id est lapidem pacientes . Colicis id est habens malum in stomaco
msItem.explicit: 116v carne . Morphea in cutes . Gonorea est fluxus spermatis inuoluntarius . udnos est sperma
msItem.note: Contains at least one medical recipe interspersed with the definitions: 'Accipe Tapsum barbarum superiorum ...'.

collation.p: Quires 11 and 13 are irregular. See the main description of the collation further details.

list.item: Quire 108-2 (ff. 76-81: 7th and 8th leaves, ff. 82-83 excised, probably blank)
Quire 1112-1 (ff. 84-95: one leaf cancelled; see above for further details)
Quire 1310-1 (ff. 104, 106-113: one leaf cancelled; see above for further details)

collation.formula: 2-38 412 58 610 7-98 108-2(7-8th leaves excised) 1112-1 (one leaf cancelled) 128 1310-1 (one leaf cancelled) 144-1 (1st leaf cancelled)

signatures.p: Quires in this Part have medieval designations in ink Roman numerals in the centre of the lower margin of the last verso of each quire - 'i-viii' for Quires 2-9 and 'x-xii' for Quires 11-13. The missing medieval designation for what would have been 'ix' (now Quire 10) suggests that the quires were numbered before the text was copied, and when Quire 10's final two leaves were cancelled, the quire designation on the original last leaf was lost.
Quires are numbered in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. The lower outer corner of the first recto in the second half of each quire is markerd with a + .

catchwords.seg: Catchwords are present in the lower inner corner of the last verso of most quires in this Part. There are catchwords present in the lower margin of f. 116v, the last verso of Quire 14, which is the last verso in this Part; the following leaf in the current volume (f. 117) begins a new Part, indicating that (at least) a quire has been lost from this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Some small holes and historic repairs from when the parchment was being prepared for writing, e.g. ff. 19, 26, 66, 69 etc. Portions of the lower part of the page (ff. 43, 81, 110) or of the outer margin (f. 50) excised. There are catchwords present in the lower margin of f. 116v, the last verso of Quire 14, which is the last verso in this Part; the following leaf in the current volume (f. 117) begins a new Part, indicating that (at least) a quire has been lost from this Part.

layout.seg: Double columns with 29-39 lines to the page, ruled in leadpoint. Written above the top line (except for f. 116v in single column).

decoNote.p: 'Arabesque' initials in red, green, dark blue and ochre (2-17 lines), throughout the manuscript. some with decorative dotting at their perimeter.

origin.origDate: Written in the second half of the 12th century.

note.p: According to M. Gullick (in a personal communication with CUL), the style of initials suggest an origin in Yorkshire or the Fenlands .

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.3.51, ff. 117r-130v

msItem.title: Medical treatise(s)

msItem.incipit: 117r curis est utendum. Recipe litargiri triti donec sit ut alcofol
msItem.finalRubric: 118v Explicit liber sextus de localibus medicinis valitudinum.

msItem.rubric: 118v Incipit liber septimus de Febribus acutis ultra etc.

msItem.note: The boundaries between the text or texts in this Part are not clearly indicated.

msItem.title: De Signis mortales in acutis
msItem.note: The boundaries between the text or texts in this Part are not clearly indicated.

msItem.title: De pulsibus
msItem.rubric: 127v Quando veneris ad egrum considera pulsum qui si fuerit deficiens
Tercium sensus consideratur secundum tenorem virtutis cuius tres sunt species.
msItem.incipit: 128r Fortis. Fortis est qui fortitudine sua videtur digitos repellere

msItem.title: Practica secundum Trotam
msItem.author: Trota of Salerno
msItem.rubric: 129r Practica Crote. Ad menstrua provocanda, propter quorum retentiones mulier concipere non potest
msItem.incipit: 129r Si ergo iuuencula fuerit, accipe radicem salicis tenere fluuit
msItem.explicit: 130v ... maturandam semen lini maluam causticum peritariam uel ... rutam artemisia
msItem.note: Chs 1-6, 9, unidentified, 10-13, 15, unidentified (5 rubricated sub-headings), 16, 21, 20, unidentified (5 rubricated sub-headings), 41 of the Cantalupo edition of the text. Chs 1-8, 11-12, unidentified, 13-17, 19, unidentified (5 rubricated sub-headings), 20, 25, 24, unidentified (5 rubricated sub-headings), 46 of the Green list of capitula to the Practica.
This text exists in two other known copies: Madrid, Biblioteca de la Universidad Complutense, MS 119, ff. 140r-144r Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Rawlinson C. 506, ff. 146v-147v
This version of the text was identified by Tuija Ainonen in 2022 as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project.

listBibl.bibl: See Latin edition and Italian translation by Piero Cantalupo (ed.), 'L'inedito opuscolo di pratica terapeutica della medichessa salernitana Trota. La Practica secundum Trotam: Testo, traduzione, appendici e glossario,' Bollettino storico di Salerno e Principato Citra 13, nos. 1-2 (1995), 1-104.

See discussion of the text by Monica H. Green (2007) 'Reconstructing the Oeuvre of Trota of Salerno', in La Scuola medica Salernitana: Gli autori e i testi, ed. Danielle Jacquart and Agostino Paravicini Bagliani, Edizione Nazionale 'La Scuola medica Salernitana', 1 (Florence: SISMEL/Edizioni del Galluzzo) ISBN 9788884502322, pp. 185-88 and 211-13.

collation.p:
Quire 15 comprises six single leaves, now stitched behind Quire 14 and of an uncertain original structure (the disposition of hair and flesh sides suggests that they may have once been part of a quire, or else have been arranged to reflect the typical arrangement of the leaves in a quire).
Quire 15six (ff. 114-122: six single leaves stitched behind Quire 14 at a later date)
Quire 168 (ff. 123-130)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower margin of f. 122v.

layout.seg: Unruled. Single columns, 35-37 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written in a cursiva script with anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Text and section titles in red throughout.
Unfilled spaces for minor initials throughout this Part.

origin.note: See Binski & Zutshi (2011) no. 55 for further information.

change.persName: Tuija Ainonen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library and Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
